occurrences.line_text: And to my wound her gratious help impart.
Marinells former wound is heald,
That of the wound he yet in languor lyes,
That that same former fatall wound of his
That th'heapes of those, which he did wound and slay,
And wyder made the wound of th'hidden dart.
This griefes deepe wound I would to thee disclose,
Yet durst she not disclose her fancies wound,
Vnto the bone, and made a griesly wound,
And also of her wound, which sore did paine,
And made a griesly wound in his enriuen side.
Torne all to rags, and rent with many a wound,
The wicked stroke did wound his enemy,
Fought many battels without wound or losse;
Or cruelly does wound, whom so she wils:
And more to make the[m] pierce & wound more deepe,
He sore doth wound, and bite, and cruelly torment.
For shame he weend a sleeping wight to wound.
That through the wound his spirit shortly did depart.
Charg'd with his speare and mortally did wound,
Hauing both sides through grypt with griesly wound.
Yet ceast he not for all that cruell wound,
Ne sparing him the more for all his grieuous wound.
Yet in his bodie made no wound nor bloud appeare.
And also for the sharpnesse of her rankling wound.
The iuyce whereof into his wound he wrought,
So as ere long he had that knightes wound
Least that the beasts sharpe teeth had any wound
And staunch the bleeding of her dreary wound.
And body haue receiu'd a mortall wound,
But also trayterously did wound her weary Knight.
No wound, which warlike hand of enemy
And al the passio[n]s heale, which wou[n]d the weaker spright.
Whom afterwards my selfe with many a wound
Words sharpely wound, but greatest griefe of scorning growes.
Fayre Pastorell, who with the selfe same wound
Ne cared she her wound in teares to steepe,
And scarsely suffring her infestred wound,
But she whose sides before with secret wound
He tooke it vp, and in his mantle wound;
All were the wounde so wide and wonderous,
A virgin widow, whose deepe wounded mind
To ï¿½sculapius brought the wounded knight:
The sad earth wounded with so sore assay,
Th'eternall bale of heauie wounded harts;
Which sinfull horror workes in wounded hart,
But his late wounded wing vnseruiceable found.
And goodly counsell, that for wounded hart
Shee sight from bottome of her wounded brest,
Such wounded beast, as that, I did not see,
That he his foe has hurt, and wounded sore,
That his deepe wounded hart in two did riue,
Who with that wicked shaft him wounded had,
She wounded had, the same along did trace
Thither they brought that wounded Squire, and layd
Their wofull harts he wounded had whyleare,
That as a Snake, still lurked in his wounded mind.
A wounded Dragon vnder him did ly,
And maske her wounded mind, both did and sayd
After he had so often wounded beene,
Or went away sore wounded of his haplesse hand.
And many knights vnhorst, and many wounded,
And all the wounded, and the weake in state,
Being fast fixed in her wounded spright,
She wounded was with her deceipts owne dart,
Which being wounded of the huntsmans hand
And left sore wounded: but when her he mist,
This knight, whom Tristram slew, had wounded sore
Done to that wounded Knight in his great need,
And was the father of that wounded Knight,
But by her wounded loue did watch all night,
But first him seemed fit, that wounded Knight
By reason that her knight was wounded sore.
And comming likewise to the wounded knight,
And eke this Squire, who likewise wounded was
For that beastes teeth, which wounded you tofore,
Like as the wounded Whale to shore flies fro[m] the maine.
Seeing the gored woundes to gape so wyde,
In wine and oyle they wash his woundes wide,
Departed thence, albe his woundes wide
And deadly woundes could heale, and reare againe
All healed of his hurts and woundes wide,
And many wide woundes launched through his inner parts.
Till she recured were of those her woundes wide.
Of their late woundes, the which the Blatant Beast
For loe the winged God, that woundeth harts,
With wounding words and termes of foule repriefe
Wherein old dints of deepe wounds did remaine,
His cruell wounds with cruddy bloud congealed,
His cunning hand gan to his wounds to lay,
Washing his bloudy wounds, that through the steele were cleft.
That with their drerie wounds and bloudy gore
Who slayes the Gyant, wounds the beast,
Which flowed from his wounds in wondrous store,
The swelling of his wounds to mitigate,
With heat, toyle, wounds, armes, smart, & inward fire
Did heale his wounds, and scorching heat alay,
Sharpe by thy wounds, but sweet the medicines bee,
So well he did her deadly wounds repaire,
He gan to comfort, and his wounds to dresse.
Through wounds, & strokes, & stubborne handeling,
His deadly wounds within my liuers swell,
Then searcht his secret wounds, and made a priefe
For their sharpe wounds, and noyous iniuries,
That mote recure their wounds: so inly they did tine.
Wounds without hurt, a bodie without might,
Through losse of bloud, which from his wounds did bleed,
And all the while his wounds were dressing, by him stayd.
Restord, and sory wounds right well recured,
Salues to his wounds, and medicines of might:
Hast drest my sinfull wounds? I kisse thy blessed feete.
Full many wounds in his corrupted flesh
That he there soiourned his wounds to heale;
Dying each day with inward wounds of dolours dart.
Had power to staunch al wounds, that mortally did bleed.
And all his wounds, and all his bruses guarisht,
Strokes, wounds, wards, weapons, all they did despise,
That by their many wounds, and carelesse harmes,
Vntill that they their wounds well healed had,
Her wounds, that vnto strength restor'd her soone anew.
Or shew the wounds, which vnto thee befell;
And these the signes, (so shewed forth his wounds)
Him to refresh, and her late wounds to heale:
Full deadly wounds, where so it is empight;
That many wounds into his flesh it made,
Till of his wounds he wexed hole and strong,
With many wounds full perilous and wyde,
To wype his wounds, and ease their bitter payning.
Into his wounds, him vp thereon did reare,
With bleeding wounds, brought home vpon a Beare
And with her teares his wounds did wash and steepe.
With wounds, is ready to forgo the ghost:
So sore her sides, so much her wounds did bleede:
That hauing there their wounds awhile redrest,
For herbes to dresse their wounds; still seeming faine,
Regardlesse of her wounds, yet bleeding rife,
For now her wounds corruption gan to breed;
Such were the wounds, the which that Blatant Beast
Their ranckling wounds, & euery day them duely drest.
One day, as he was searching of their wounds,
Their wounds recur'd, and forces reincreast,
Through many wounds, which lately he in fight
And griesly wounds that him appalled sore.
Witnesse the wounds, and this wyde bloudie lake,
To his wounds worker, that with louely dart
More ample spirit, then hitherto was wount,
It chaunst a sort of merchants, which were wount
And being once amisse growes daily wourse and wourse.
And being once amisse growes daily wourse and wourse.
With looks, with words, with gifts he oft her wowed;
Defowled, and their Lady dresse his wownd,
And insolent wox through vnwonted ease,
Th'old woman wox half blanck, those words to heare;
He wox right blyth, as he had got thereby,
He woxe dismayd, and gan his fate to feare;
Carelesse the man soone woxe, and his weake wit
Woxe sore affraid, and standing still a space,
Tho when this breathlesse woxe, that batteil gan renew.
Nigh his wits end then woxe th'amazed knight,
That all the three thereat woxe much afrayd,
The royall Mayd woxe inly wondrous glad,
She woxe; yet wist she neither how, nor why,
All suddenly dim woxe the dampish ayre,
So still his hart woxe sore, and health decayd:
And woxe halfe wroth against her damzels slacke,
The foolish man thereat woxe wondrous blith,
But lookt on Glauce grim, who woxe afeard
He woxe full blithe, as he had got thereby,
Beheld, he woxe therewith displeased sore,
And woxe nigh mad for very harts despight,
But when the world woxe old, it woxe warre old
But when the world woxe old, it woxe warre old
The traines of wit, in wickednesse woxe bold,
Which when that Squire beheld, he woxe full glad
He woxe, that lenger he note stand vpright,
And woxe inclined much vnto her part,
He woxe halfe mad, and in that rage gan roue
He wearie woxe, and backe return'd againe
He woxe nigh mad with wrath and fell despight,
Then Coridon woxe frollicke, that earst seemed dead.
Through vnaduized rashnesse woxen wood;
And quickning faith, that earst was woxen weake,
And all his sinews woxen weake and raw,
Was woxen strong, and left her fruitfull nest;
Till that her sisters children, woxen strong
Spoild of their rosie red, were woxen pale and wan.
Is woxen so deform'd, that he has quight
All woxen weary of their iournall toyle:
But Scudamour now woxen inly glad,
And through long fasting woxen pale and wan,
Now when as Calepine was woxen strong,
That lay in waite her wrack for to bewaile,
Thinking to worke on her his vtmost wracke,
And on their foes did worke full cruell wracke:
Or else by wracke, that wretches hath distrest,
Of that faire bootie, and with bitter wracke
Fearelesse of foes, or fortunes wrackfull yre,
Cannot endure, but needs it must be wrackt
In couert vele, and wrap in shadowes light,
To do fowle death to dye, or wrap in grieuous woe.
From mortall vew, and wrap in darkenesse dreare;
Or wrapped be in loues of former Dame,
Wrapped in wretched cares and hearts vnrest,
Came to the place, where when he wrapped found
Tho wrapping vp her wrethed sterne arownd,
God helpe the man so wrapt in Errours endlesse traine.
Wrapt in eternall silence farre from enemyes.
The which his naked sides he wrapt abouts;
Weake wretch I wrapt my selfe in Palmers weed,
Their feet vnshod, their bodies wrapt in rags,
And wrapt in fetters of a golden tresse,
Wrapt in great dolours and in deadly feares,
Couer'd with cold, and wrapt in wretchednesse,
The gentle bloud, how euer it be wrapt
That by no meanes it backe againe he forth could wrast.
With liuing bloud he those characters wrate,
And sad Proserpines wrath, them to affright.
Pricked with wrath and fiery fierce disdaine,
And full of wrath, that with his sharp-head speare
The instruments of wrath and heauinesse:
Tho mou'd with wrath, and shame, and Ladies sake,
The wrath of thundring Ioue, that rules both night and day?
Where foming wrath, their cruell tuskes they whet,
Inflam'd with scornefull wrath and high disdaine,
And calmd his wrath with goodly temperance.
Against the day of wrath, to burden thee?
And euer burning wrath before him laid,
And wrath, and hatred warely to shonne,
That drew on men Gods hatred, and his wrath,
And his auenging wrath to clemencie incline.
Was swolne with wrath, & poyson, & with bloudy gore.
Did burne with wrath, and sparkled liuing fyre;
The knight was wrath to see his stroke beguyld,
Inflam'd with wrath, his raging blade he heft,
Thus when that Princes wrath was pacifide,
And suffred not in wrath his hastie steps to stray.
Imprinted had that token of his wrath,
O fly from wrath, fly, O my liefest Lord:
Besides he feard her wrath, and threatned shot
That might him moue to wrath, and indignation reare.
Occasion, the root of all wrath and despight.
To wreake my wrath on him, that first it wrought.
Wrath, gelosie, griefe, loue this Squire haue layd thus low.
Wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue do thus expell:
Wrath is a fire, and gealosie a weede,
So shall wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue dye and decay.
And breathes out wrath and hainous crueltie;
Occasion to wrath, and cause of strife;
Nath'lesse now quench thy whot emboyling wrath:
But griefe and wrath, that be her enemies,
The wrath, which Atin kindled in his mind,
Mammon emmoued was with inward wrath;
To wreake your wrath on this dead seeming knight,
And wrath, he to him leaped furiously,
Breathing out wrath, and bellowing disdaine,
Whereat renfierst with wrath and sharpe regret,
Who, had he not with wrath outrageous,
Flying from Iunoes wrath and hard assay,
And some for wrath, to see their captiue Dame:
Full of disdainefull wrath, he fierce vprose,
To slake your wrath, and mollifie your mind,
Ne shall he yet his wrath so mitigate,
O do thy cruell wrath and spightfull wrong
Her former sorrow into suddein wrath,
To wreake the wrath, which he did earst reuiue
At last through wrath and vengeaunce making way,
At last turning her feare to foolish wrath,
All full of wrath, thus fiercely him bespake;
The instrument of wrath, and with the same
And touched was with secret wrath and shame
And oft in wrath he thence againe vprose;
And oft in wrath he layd him downe againe.
Nathelesse she full of wrath for that late stroke,
That in her wrath she thought them both haue thrild,
Or wrath of cruell wight on thee ywrake?
That her inburning wrath she gan abate,
Whereat the Prince full wrath, his strong right hand
T'asswage his wrath, and pardon their mesprise.
When so he list in wrath lift vp his steely brand.
To wreake your wrath on such a carle as hee:
Weening at once her wrath on him to wreake,
Through vengeful wrath & sdeignfull pride half mad:
Of her fierce wrath, and backward still retyre,
With sodaine stounds of wrath and griefe attone:
The one of them, which most her wrath increast,
Snatching at euery thing, doth wreake her wrath
And when in wrath he threats the worlds decay,
Latonaes childrens wrath, that all her issue wasted.
Wherewith all full of wrath, she thus replyde;
Yet he, that could his wrath full wisely guyde,
His wrath on him, that first occasion broke.
Then as it were t'auenge his wrath on mee,
That ye will not your wrath vpon him wreake,
He woxe nigh mad with wrath and fell despight,
Fled from his wrath, and did themselues conuay
So both to wreake their wrathes on Britomart agreed.
Her wrathful hand from greedy vengeance to haue stayd.
The false witch did my wrathfull hand with-hold;
His suddein eye, flaming with wrathfull fyre,
And turning wrathfull fire to lustfull heat,
Both breathing vengeaunce, both of wrathfull hew:
As when almightie Ioue in wrathfull mood,
The proud Duessa full of wrathfull spight,
Whose wrathfull wreakes them selues do now alay.
The wrathfull beast about him turned light,
When wintry storme his wrathfull wreck does threat,
That heapd on him so many wrathfull wreakes:
Against themselues turning their wrathfull spight,
And thousand furies wait on wrathfull sword;
My wrathfull will, and do for mercy call.
With wrathfull hand I slew her innocent;
T'auoide the rash assault and wrathfull stowre
So pleased, did his wrathfull purpose faire appease.
With wrathfull fire his courage kindled bright,
Sith wrathfull hand wrought not her owne desire?
Or wrathfull Neptune did them driue before
His wrathfull will with reason to asswage,
To which he turned in his wrathfull stound,
Her wrathfull steele, that none mote it abide;
Her clowdy care into a wrathfull stowre,
Such vs'd wise Glauce to that wrathfull knight,
The wicked weapon heard his wrathfull vow,
Their wrathfull blades downe fell out of their hand,
All that long while vpheld her wrathfull hand,
Therewith her wrathfull courage gan appall,
The wrathfull weapon gainst his countnance bold:
Relent the rigour of your wrathfull will,
Time to my will, and from his wrathfull sight
Yet held her wrathfull hand from vengeance sore,
If wrathfull wight, then fowle rebuke and shame
Who all the while beheld their wrathfull moode,
Whom soone as they with wrathfull eie bewraide,
And sailers saue from wreckes of wrathfull winde.
Together stroue, and kindled wrathfull fires:
And then she in her wrathfull will did cast,
He mote not come, to wreake his wrathfull mood.
As when the wrathfull Boreas doth bluster,
And hauing somewhat calm'd his wrathfull heat
With wrathfull fury for so foule a shame,
And laying hand vpon his wrathfull blade,
The wrathfull Prince, & wrought her husbands peace,
Then to the rest his wrathfull hand he bends,
In winters wrathfull time, he forced him to flie.
To serue the vengeaunce of his wrathfull will;
With that his sword he drew all wrathfully,
So they him left, inflam'd with wrathfulnesse,
Them from the tempest of his wrathfulnesse,
And some of cats, that wrawling still did cry,
Where brothers death to wreak Sansioy
A cruell witch her cursed will to wreake,
Anothers wrongs to wreake vpon thy selfe:
To wreake the guilt of mortall sins is bent,
But wanted sword to wreake his enmitee.
That mote him honour win, to wreake so foule despight.
That I may wreake on them their hainous hatefull deed.
But still prouokt her sonne to wreake her wrong;
To wreake my wrath on him, that first it wrought.
To wreake it selfe on beast all innocent,
With cruell purpose bent to wreake on him
Yet since no way is left to wreake my spight,
To wreake your wrath on this dead seeming knight,
On this vile bodie from to wreake my wrong,
But wreake your wrongs wrought to this knight alone,
The which I seeke to wreake, and Arthegall he hight.
On his sonne Edwin all those wrongs shall wreake;
To wreake the wrath, which he did earst reuiue
Great wreake to many errant knights of yore,
And wreake your sorrow on your cruell foe,
He now vnable was to wreake his old despight.
This day, to wreake the dammage by thee donne:
Why do I not it wreake, on thee now in my might?
On whom I waite to wreake that foule despight,
So both to wreake their wrathes on Britomart agreed.
Or wreake on him her will for so great iniurie.
Till I her find, and wreake on him that her did reaue.
So on him selfe to wreake his follies owne despight.
Hath done this wrong, to wreake on worthlesse wight
Vpon the sea to wreake his fell intent;
To wreake your wrath on such a carle as hee:
Weening at once her wrath on him to wreake,
There they did thinke them selues on her to wreake:
Vpon your selues anothers wrong to wreake?
He mote not come, to wreake his wrathfull mood.
To wreake her on that mayden messengere,
Snatching at euery thing, doth wreake her wrath
To wreake on me the guilt of his owne wrong.
That ye will not your wrath vpon him wreake,
To this attempt, to wreake his hid despight,
He glad of life, and willing eke to wreake
And wreake him selfe on them, that him despise.
Or if that dead, how he her death might wreake,
Whose wrathfull wreakes them selues do now alay.
That heapd on him so many wrathfull wreakes:
Or bide the horror of his wreakfull hand,
And from so heauie sight his head did wreath,
And round about the wreath this word was writ,
With golden wreath and gorgeous ornament;
His wast was with a wreath of yuie greene
Whose wreathed boughts when euer he vnfoldes,
That with her wreathed taile her middle did enfold.
Their clasping armes, in wanton wreathings intricate.
When wintry storme his wrathfull wreck does threat,
Threatning vnheedie wrecke and rash decay,
That workst such wrecke on her, to whom thou dearest art.
To wrecke on them their follies hardyment:
And shiuered ships, which had bene wrecked late,
And wreckes of many wretches, which did weepe,
For which he others wrongs, and wreckes himselfe;
And sailers saue from wreckes of wrathfull winde.
Where warres, and wreckes, and wicked enmitie
Were brought by errour, or by wreckfull wynde.
Either by being wreckt vppon the sands,
His sunbroad shield about his wrest he bond,
And many-folded shield he bound about his wrest.
And Guyons shield about his wrest he bond;
Adowne he kest it with so puissant wrest,
Tryde all her arts, & all her sleights, thence out to wrest.
The maistring raines out of her weary wrest,
The wicked weapon rashly he did wrest,
It forth to wrest, the staffe a sunder brake,
To blot the same with blame, or wrest in wicked sort.
Long did he wrest and wring it to and fro,
So vnto wrong to yield my wrested right:
Their shining shieldes about their wrestes they tye,
Some wrestle, some do run, some bathe in christall flood.
And wrestle wantonly, ne car'd to hyde,
Did chalenge Calidore to wrestling game:
Hyponeo, with salt bedewed wrests:
Vnworthy wretch (quoth he) of so great grace,
What comfort can I wofull wretch conceaue,
To let a wearie wretch from her dew rest,
Weake wretch I wrapt my selfe in Palmers weed,
Ah wretch (quoth he) thy destinies withstand
So me weake wretch, of many weakest one,
Then gan the cursed wretch aloud to cry,
Another wretch, whose carkasse deepe was drent
Vnthankfull wretch (said he) is this the meed,
Me seely wretch she so at vauntage caught,
Of filthy wretch? well may shee you reproue
And eke reward the wretch for his mesprise,
Vnworthy wretch to tread vpon the ground,
And vassall to the vilest wretch aliue,
That liuing thus, a wretch and louing so,
For lending life to me a wretch vnkind;
The wretch, that hyr'd you to this wicked deed.
Many a wretch, for want of remedie,
That maketh wretch or happie, rich or poore:
Die is my dew: yet rew my wretched state
The wretched woman, whom vnhappy howre
And to this wretched Lady, my deare loue,
Wretched man, wretched tree; whose nature weake,
Wretched man, wretched tree; whose nature weake,
And by my wretched louers side me pight,
Which euer after in most wretched case,
He led a wretched life vnto him selfe vnknowne.
Most wretched wight, whom nothing might suffise,
And said, Ah wretched sonne of wofull syre,
Her wicked dayes with wretched knife did end,
Of caytiue wretched thrals, that wayled night and day.
Besides the endlesse routs of wretched thralles,
The wretched payre transform'd to treen mould;
And now in darkesome dungeon, wretched thrall,
The roote of all your care, and wretched plight,
Thou wretched man, of death hast greatest need,
Of wretched soules, and helpe the helpelesse pore:
That wretched world he gan for to abhore,
That he desirde to end his wretched dayes:
With which bare wretched wights he dayly clad,
(Quoth he) as wretched, and liu'd in like paine.
But wretched we, where ye haue left your marke,
Yet can they not warne death from wretched wight.
Which plunged had faire Ladie in so wretched state.
But sith this wretched woman ouercome
I witnesse am, and this their wretched sonne,
To heape more vengeance on that wretched wight;
Turning about he saw that wretched Squire,
O wretched man, that would abuse so gentle Dame.
Then gan the Palmer thus, most wretched man,
To rid a wretched man from hands of hellish wight.
Wilfully make thy selfe a wretched thrall,
Most wretched woman, and of wicked race,
That am, I weene, most wretched man aliue,
To saue my Lord, in wretched plight forlore;
There is: else much more wretched were the cace
The wretched man gan then auise too late,
Till wearie of that wretched life, her selfe she hong.
In wretched prison long he did remaine,
Enwombed was, from wretched Adams line
With wretched miseries, and woefull ruth,
Her wretched dayes in dolour she mote wast,
Nought like (quoth she) for that same wretched boy
From Armoricke, where long in wretched cace
The wretched sonne of wretched mother borne,
The wretched sonne of wretched mother borne,
And doth for wretched mens reliefe make way;
To succour wretched wights, whom we captiued see.
Me seemes I see Amintas wretched fate,
And came at last in weary wretched plight
And makes ensample of mans wretched state,
The wretched man hearing her call for ayd,
